{{About|the stadium of AFC Ajax|the stadium of FC Barcelona|Estadi Johan Cruyff}} {{Use British English|date=September 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Johan Cruyff Arena | fullname = Johan Cruijff Arena | nickname = De Arena | former_names = {{nowrap|Amsterdam Arena (1996–2018)}} | logo_image = Johan Cruijff ArenA logo.png | logo_size = 250 | image = Amsterdam ArenA1.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA]]''' {{rating|4|4}} | location = ArenA Boulevard 1, 1101 AX [[Amsterdam]], Netherlands | coordinates = {{coord|52|18|51|N|4|56|31|E|display=inline,title|region:NL_source:nlwiki}} | broke_ground = | built = 1993–1996 | opened = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1996|8|14}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Gemeente Amsterdam]]
Stadion Amsterdam N.V. | operator = | surface = PlayMaster Hybrid Grass by Tarkett Sports | construction_cost = €140 million | record_attendance = 53,320 (Ajax 2–0 Feyenoord on 21 January 2018) | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | tenants = [[AFC Ajax]] (1996–present)
[[Amsterdam Admirals]] (1997–2007)
[[Netherlands national football team]] (selected matches) | seating_capacity = 54,990
68,000 (concerts) | dimensions = 105 x 68 m | suites = 76 }} The '''Johan Cruyff Arena''' ({{lang-nl|Johan Cruijff Arena}} {{IPA-nl|ˈjoːɦɑn ˈkrœyf aːˌreːnaː|}}; officially stylised as ''Johan Cruijff ArenA'') is the main stadium of the Dutch capital city of [[Amsterdam]]. Built from 1993 to 1996 at a cost equivalent to €140 million, it is the largest stadium in the country. The stadium was previously known as the '''Amsterdam Arena''' (stylised as ''Amsterdam ArenA'') until the 2018–19 football season, when the stadium was officially renamed in honour of legendary Dutch footballer [[Johan Cruyff]] after he passed away in March 2016. The stadium is the home of the [[association football]] club [[AFC Ajax]] since 1996. In addition, it was the home of the now-defunct American football club [[Amsterdam Admirals]] (1997–2007). It was one of the stadiums used during [[UEFA Euro 2000|Euro 2000]], and also held the [[1998 UEFA Champions League Final|1998 Champions League]] and [[2013 UEFA Europa League Final|2013 Europa League]] finals. The stadium will also host three group stage matches and one match in the round of 16 of the [[UEFA Euro 2020|Euro 2020]]. Both international and Dutch artists have given concerts in the stadium, including [[Coldplay]], [[Take That]], [[Celine Dion]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Michael Jackson]], [[André Hazes]], [[David Bowie]], [[AC/DC]], [[One Direction]], [[The Rolling Stones]], [[Beyoncé]] and [[Rihanna]]. The dance event [[Sensation (event)|Sensation]] was held in the stadium every year, up until the final edition in 2017. The stadium has a [[retractable roof]] combined with a grass surface. It has a [[seating capacity|capacity]] of 54,990 people during football matches,{{cite web|url=https://www.johancruijffarena.nl/Stadion-omgeving/Spreekbeurt.htm|title=Houd je spreekbeurt over de Johan Cruijff ArenA|website=Johan Cruijff ArenA|accessdate=22 August 2018}} and of 68,000 people during concerts if a centre-stage setup is used (the stage in the middle of the pitch); for end-stage concerts, the capacity is 50,000, and for concerts for which the stage is located in the east side of the stadium, the capacity is 35,000. It held UEFA five-star stadium status, which was superseded by a new system of classification. ==History== {{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=left|image1=Amsterdam Arena Roof Open.jpg|image2=Amsterdam Arena Roof Closed.jpg|width=200|caption2=The Johan Cruyff Arena with the [[retractable roof]] opened and closed}} Amsterdam was one of six cities that bid to host the [[1992 Summer Olympics]]. In 1986, a new Olympic stadium was designed, with a football field and an athletics track. It was to be built in the area of Strandvliet in [[Amsterdam Zuidoost]]. After Amsterdam lost the bid to [[Barcelona]] in October 1986, the plans for the new stadium were abandoned. In 1987, the Stichting Amsterdam Sportstad (English: "Amsterdam Sports City Foundation") was established, which made new plans for a sports stadium with an all-seated capacity of 55,000. In 1990, a new design was made based on both previous designs, with a football field, an athletics track, and completely covered by a roof. By this time, [[AFC Ajax]] needed a new stadium, as their old stadium, [[De Meer Stadion|De Meer]], was far too small for most of Ajax's games. For several years, Ajax had moved its more important games to [[Olympisch Stadion (Amsterdam)|Olympisch Stadion]].{{nl icon}} [http://www.amsterdamarena.nl/filestore/?dl=258 The making of Amsterdam ArenA] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090130052349/http://www.amsterdamarena.nl/filestore/?dl=258 |date=30 January 2009 }} Amsterdam ArenA. Retrieved 8 June 2008 Once more, the design was altered – the athletics track was removed, the capacity was reduced to 50,000 seats, and the fixed roof was replaced by a [[retractable roof]]. In 1992, the [[Government of Amsterdam]] authorised the plans for the stadium with a ''Transferium'' where people could transfer from their car to various forms of public transportation. In 1993, the Government of Amsterdam changed the development plan of the location and gave a permit to build the stadium. The first pile of the [[deep foundation]] of the stadium was placed on 26 November 1993. The construction work, undertaken by [[Ballast Nedam]] and [[Royal BAM Group]], took almost three years. The highest point of the building was reached on 24 February 1995, after the roof construction was raised. The fly-over from the public road to the parking facilities was opened on 13 March 1996. The stadium received 180,000 visitors during the construction work, until the stadium was closed from 1 July 1996 until the opening ceremony. The stadium was officially opened on 14 August 1996 by [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Queen Beatrix]].{{nl icon}} [http://www.amsterdamarena.nl/over_amsterdam_arena/wist_je_dat/ Wist je dat...]. Amsterdam ArenA. Retrieved 8 June 2008 [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Queen Beatrix]] opened the stadium by making a curtain fall inside the stadium. This revealed the world's largest painting ''De Zee'' (English: ''The Sea'') of {{convert|80|×|126|m}}. Two-dimensional ships were placed on the sea representing the clubs in the ''[[Eredivisie]]''.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} [[Tina Turner]] opened the stadium with three concerts with 160,000 people in the arena, from her world breaking [[Wildest Dreams Tour]]. [[Trijntje Oosterhuis]] sang the [[hymn]] "De Zee", composed for the opening ceremony by [[John Ewbank (composer)|John Ewbank]]. An eight-day [[Olympic torch relay|torch relay]] with 375 runners over 1400 kilometres through the Netherlands reached the stadium. The first runner was [[Johan Cruyff]] starting in the old stadium De Meer, and the last runner was [[Frank Rijkaard]] arriving in the new stadium. After the grass was revealed and the roof opened, an inaugural football match was played between AFC Ajax and [[A.C. Milan|Milan]]. The construction of the stadium cost €140 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.amsterdamarena.nl/docs/pdf_facts_figures.pdf |title=Facts & figures |accessdate=9 June 2008 |language=Dutch |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090407084136/http://www.amsterdamarena.nl/docs/pdf_facts_figures.pdf |archivedate=7 April 2009}} The stadium combines a retractable roof with a grass surface. This caused some problems in the beginning: the grass rolls would not grow in the shade of the open roof and had to be replaced up to four times a year.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} ===Exterior renovation=== In September 2015, plans were presented to renovate the stadium's facade.{{cite web |url=https://www.amsterdamarena.nl/article-tonen-op-pagina/amsterdam-arena-presenteert-nieuwbouwplannen-2020.htm |title=Amsterdam ArenA presenteert nieuwbouwplannen 2020 |language=Dutch |date=30 September 2015 |publisher=Amsterdam Arena}} The renovation should provide better quality and service to visitors by widening the walkway rings around the stadium, creating more room for the visitors and for new facilities (the number of seats remains the same). As a result, the outside of the stadium transforms from a concave shape to a convex shape, drastically altering its appearance. The renovation is planned to be completed in 2020, when 4 matches of the [[UEFA Euro 2020]] championship will be played in the Arena. Construction works started in June 2017.{{cite web |url=https://www.parool.nl/amsterdam/verbouwing-johan-cruijff-arena-is-van-start~a4503005/ |title=Verbouwing Johan Cruijff Arena is van start |language=Dutch |date=27 June 2017 |publisher=Het Parool}} The first phase is to renovate the east side of the stadium, where construction of the new facade was completed in April 2018.{{cite web |url=https://www.amsterdamarena.nl/article-tonen-op-pagina/ruwbouw-oostzijde-amsterdam-arena-klaar.htm |title=Ruwbouw oostzijde Amsterdam ArenA klaar |language=Dutch |date=5 April 2018 |publisher=Amsterdam Arena}} ===Name change=== [[File:Amsterdam Arena logo.svg|thumb|Former stadium logo until 2018]] On 25 April 2017, it was announced that the Amsterdam Arena would be renamed to "Johan Cruijff Arena" in memory of Ajax legend [[Johan Cruyff]].{{cite web |url=http://nos.nl/artikel/2170167-amsterdam-arena-wordt-johan-cruijff-arena.html |title=Amsterdam Arena wordt Johan Cruijff Arena |trans-title=Amsterdam Arena becomes Johan Cruijff Arena |website=nos.nl |publisher=[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]] |date=25 April 2017 |access-date=25 April 2017 |language=Dutch}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ajax.nl/streams/ajax-actueel/intentieovereenkomst-amsterdam-arena-wordt-johan-cruijff-arena-.htm|title=Amsterdam ArenA wordt Johan Cruijff ArenA|publisher=Ajax Amsterdam|language=dutch|date=25 April 2017}} Later that year, on 9 August, it was stated that the name change would take place on 25 October 2017.{{cite web |url=http://www.voetbalzone.nl/doc.asp?uid=310603 |title=Thuishaven Ajax heet vanaf eind oktober officieel Johan Cruijff ArenA |language=Dutch |date=9 August 2017 |publisher=Voetbalzone}}{{cite web |url=https://www.vi.nl/nieuws/johan-cruijff-arena-op-25-oktober-eindelijk-een-feit |title=Johan Cruijff Arena op 25 oktober eindelijk een feit |language=Dutch |date=9 August 2017 |publisher=Voetbal International}} However, this was postponed as that date proved to be infeasable due to the many matters that needed to be settled, such as arranging compensation for possible loss of income, transferring part of the shares from the municipality of Amsterdam to Ajax and having a discussion with the Cruyff family.{{cite web |url=https://www.vi.nl/nieuws/officiele-naamswijziging-johan-cruijff-arena-uitgesteld |title=Officiële naamswijziging Johan Cruijff Arena uitgesteld |language=Dutch |date=19 October 2017 |publisher=Voetbal International}}{{cite web |url=http://www.at5.nl/artikelen/174388/officile-naamswijziging-johan-cruijff-arena-uitgesteld |title=Officiële naamswijziging Johan Cruijff Arena uitgesteld |language=Dutch |date=19 October 2017 |publisher=AT5}} On 5 April 2018, it was announced that the stadium would officially change name at the start of the 2018–19 football season.{{cite web |url=http://www.amsterdamarena.nl/article-tonen-op-pagina/-amsterdam-arena-wordt-officieel-johan-cruijff-arena-.htm |title=Amsterdam ArenA wordt officieel Johan Cruijff ArenA |language=Dutch |date=5 April 2018 |publisher=Amsterdam Arena}}{{cite web |url=https://www.ajax.nl/streams/actueel/amsterdam-arena-wordt-officieel-johan-cruijff-arena-.htm |title=Amsterdam ArenA wordt officieel Johan Cruijff ArenA |language=Dutch |date=5 April 2018 |publisher=Ajax}} The stadium's new logo was revealed on 25 April 2018, the birthday of Johan Cruyff.{{cite web |url=https://www.nu.nl/voetbal/5239133/logo-johan-cruijff-arena-onthuld-frank-rijkaard.html |title=Logo Johan Cruijff Arena onthuld door Frank Rijkaard |language=Dutch |date=25 April 2018 |publisher=Nu.nl}} According to the spokeswoman of Cruyff's family, the original Dutch spelling of his name (''Cruijff'') was chosen for the stadium's official name "to stay close to the Dutch Johan".{{cite web |url=https://www.nu.nl/voetbal/5208320/familie-cruijff-blij-naamsverandering-arena-eindelijk-feit.html |title=Familie Cruijff blij dat naamsverandering Arena eindelijk een feit is |language=Dutch |date=5 April 2018 |publisher=Nu.nl}} The 2018–19 football season started in August 2018.{{cite web |url=https://www.knvb.nl/nieuws/betaald-voetbal/eredivisie/45675/aftrap-seizoen-201819-eredivisie-op-10-augustus |title=Aftrap seizoen 2018/'19 in Eredivisie op 10 augustus |language=Dutch |date=22 January 2018 |publisher=[[KNVB]]}} ==Building and facilities== The stadium's original architect is Rob Schuurman (from the Netherlands). Its all-seated capacity is 54,990. During music concerts, the stadium has a maximum capacity of 68,000 visitors. The parking capacity of the ''Transferium'' is 500 cars (inside); there are an additional 12,000 spots outside. The Johan Cruyff Arena is one of two stadiums in the Netherlands that is rated as [[UEFA stadium categories|Category 4]] by [[UEFA]], the other being the [[Feijenoord Stadion]] in [[Rotterdam]].[https://www.worldstadiumdatabase.com/list-of-uefa-category-4-stadiums.htm List of UEFA Category 4 Stadiums] World Stadium Database. Retrieved 4 August 2018 The Ajax Museum is located in the stadium, which shows Ajax's more than 100 years of history.[http://english.ajax.nl/web/show/id=49214 The Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617184749/http://english.ajax.nl/web/show/id%3D49214 |date=17 June 2008 }} AFC Ajax. Retrieved 9 June 2008 The nearest train station is [[Amsterdam Bijlmer Arena]]. ==Sport events== ===Association football=== [[File:Amsterdam Arena .jpg|thumb|Photo from Netherlands-France friendly match, interrupted on 14th minute as a tribute to Johan Cruyff.]] The inaugural match was between the home team [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] and [[A.C. Milan|Milan]], which ended with a 3–0 win for Milan. The first goal was scored by [[Dejan Savićević]]. The stadium is the home of [[AFC Ajax]] in the [[Eredivisie]]. The [[1998 UEFA Champions League Final]] when [[Real Madrid]] defeated [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], was played in the arena. It was also one of the venues in [[UEFA Euro 2000]]. The stadium hosts most of the [[Netherlands national football team|Dutch national team]]'s matches, though the Netherlands no longer has a dedicated [[national stadium]] for football. In addition, the arena hosts friendly matches for other Dutch national football teams. [[File:The Netherlands vs Kazakhstan (3-1) at Amsterdam Arena, 10 October 2014.jpg|thumb|[[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying Group A|Euro 2016 qualifier]] match between Netherlands and Kazakhstan.]] ====Euro 2000 matches==== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date !! !! Result !! !! Round |- | 11 June 2000 || {{fb|NED}} || 1–0 || {{fb|CZE}} || [[UEFA Euro 2000 Group D|Group D]] |- | 18 June 2000 || {{fb|SVN}} || 1–2 || {{fb|ESP}} || [[UEFA Euro 2000 Group C|Group C]] |- | 21 June 2000 || {{fb|FRA}} || 2–3 || {{fb|NED}} || [[UEFA Euro 2000 Group D|Group D]] |- | 24 June 2000 || {{fb|TUR}} || 0–2 || {{fb|POR}} || Quarter-finals |- | 29 June 2000 || {{fb|NED}} || 0–0 (aet)
(1–3 p) || {{fb|ITA}} || Semi-finals |} After the death of [[Rinus Michels]] in 2005, [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] fans tried to convince the stadium's board to rebrand the stadium as the Rinus Michels Stadium. The board declined. At every Ajax home game, however, fans bring a large banner displaying the words 'Rinus Michels Stadion'. The stadium was the host of [[2013 UEFA Europa League Final]], when [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] defeated [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] 2–1. ===Euro 2020=== The Johan Cruyff Arena is one of the stadiums that will host matches for [[UEFA Euro 2020]]. ===American football=== The stadium was also the home of the [[American football]] team [[Amsterdam Admirals]] of the [[NFL Europe]], until the [[National Football League]] (NFL) ended its European competition in June 2007.{{nl icon}} [http://www.nrc.nl/anp/sport/article731143.ece Admirals houdt op te bestaan] [[NRC Handelsblad]], 29 June 2007. Retrieved 8 June 2008 The team played over 50 matches in the stadium from 1997 to 2007. [[World Bowl IX]] was played at the Arena in 2001, when the [[Berlin Thunder]] defeated the [[Barcelona Dragons]]. ===Kickboxing=== As [[kickboxing]] is the most popular combat sport in the Netherlands, the [[It's Showtime (kickboxing)|It's Showtime]] and [[K-1]] promotions have held a number of fight cards at the arena. Many of the sport's biggest stars such as [[Peter Aerts]], [[Semmy Schilt]], [[Badr Hari]] and [[Ernesto Hoost]] have fought there.[http://www.hd.net/fear-and-loathing-in-amsterdam/ "Fear and Loathing in Amsterdam" by Michael Schiavello]. Hd.net. ==Music events== [[File:Coldplay perform "Adventure of a Lifetime", Amsterdam Arena, June 2016 (5).jpg|thumb|British pop rock band [[Coldplay]] performing at the stadium, as part of their [[A Head Full of Dreams Tour]], in June 2016.]] Despite frequent complaints {{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} about the acoustics of the Arena, concerts are often held in the stadium. [[Tina Turner]] was the first to perform at the arena during her ''[[Wildest Dreams Tour]]'', with more than 157,000 people attending the three sold-out concerts on 6–8 September 1996. [[Michael Jackson]] performed at the arena during his ''[[HIStory World Tour]]'' in five sold-out concerts, on 28, 30 September; 2 October 1996 and 8 & 10 June 1997, for a total audience of 250,000 fans.[http://mjbaltic.com/Tours/Dates_History_Tour.htm HIStory World Tour – Tour Dates] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202155910/http://mjbaltic.com/Tours/Dates_History_Tour.htm |date=2 February 2010 }}. Mjbaltic.com. [[The Rolling Stones]] performed at the stadium eight times: the first, the second, the third, the fourth and the fifth were on 29 June and 1, 2, 5 and 6 July 1998 during their [[Bridges to Babylon Tour]], in front of a total sold out crowd of 261,277 people. The sixth and the seventh were on 19 August – 22 September 2003 during their [[Licks Tour]]. The eighth one was on 31 July 2006 during their [[A Bigger Bang (concert tour)|A Bigger Bang]]. [[Backstreet Boys]] performed at the stadium on 5 June 1999 during [[Into the Millennium Tour]]. The largest number of visitors visited the Arena for the concert of [[Celine Dion|Céline Dion]] during her [[Let's Talk About Love World Tour]]. 68,083 spectators heard Dion on a heart-shaped stage in the middle of the stadium. [[Bon Jovi]] performed at the stadium four times: the first and the second were on 5 and 6 June 2001 during their [[One Wild Night Tour]]. The third one was on 3 June 2003 during their [[Bounce Tour]]. The fourth one was on 13 June 2008 during their [[Lost Highway Tour]], in front of a sold out crowd of 34,512 people. [[Robbie Williams]] played the venue eight times: twice in July 2003 as part of [[2003 Tour (Robbie Williams)|Weekends of Mass Distraction]]; four dates in June 2006, as part of his [[Close Encounters Tour]]; and on 13 July 2013 during the [[Take The Crown Stadium Tour]]. He also performed on 18 July 2011 as member of [[Take That]] during their [[Progress Live|Progress Live tour]]. [[David Bowie]] performed a concert in the arena as part of his [[A Reality Tour]] on 11 June 2004. [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]] performed at the stadium on 1 July 2007 during their [[Turn It On Again: The Tour]]. The performances of "[[Turn It On Again]]" and "[[No Son of Mine]]" were recorded for the group's live album ''[[Live over Europe 2007]]''. [[U2]] performed at the stadium seven times: the first, the second and the third were on 13, 15, and 16 July 2005 during their [[Vertigo Tour]], in front of a total sold out crowd of 165,516 people. The fourth and the fifth were on 20 and 21 July 2009 during their [[U2 360° Tour]], in front of a total sold out crowd of 125,886 people. The band's sixth and seventh shows were for their [[The Joshua Tree Tour 2017]] on 29 and 30 July 2017. [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] has performed at three different dates, with all tickets sold out. There were two presentations by the [[Confessions Tour]] in 2006 and one presentation by [[Sticky & Sweet Tour]] in 2008. Dutch music group [[De Toppers]] have played the venue 42 times since 2005. No other act has performed in the arena that often. In October 2008, the stadium was home to Dutch children's group [[Kinderen voor Kinderen]]. The Arena was selected because of the seating requirement for the group's new format of concert called the "Mega Spektakel". The group had two concerts in the stadium on the same day due to high volume of people, mostly children that attended. [[AC/DC]] performed a show on 23 June 2009 as part of their [[Black Ice World Tour]] The stadium is also host to dance event [[Sensation (event)|Sensation]]. [[André Rieu]] and his orchestra plus about 650 brass instrument players had a huge concert in 2011. [[Muse (band)|Muse]] performed a show on 4 June 2013 as part of their [[The 2nd Law World Tour]]. On 8 September 2013 former [[Pink Floyd]] member [[Roger Waters]] will perform a show of his [[The Wall Live (concert tour)|The Wall Live]] Concert Tour. On 24 and 25 June 2014, boy band [[One Direction]] performed in the arena as a part of their Where We Are Tour. [[Rihanna]] performed at the venue as a part of her [[Anti World Tour]] on 17 June 2016. [[Coldplay]] performed 2 concerts on 23 June 2016 and 24 June 2016 as a part of their [[A Head Full of Dreams Tour]]. [[Beyoncé]] performed at the venue on 16 July 2016 as a part of her [[Formation World Tour]]. The concert sold out within 20 minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.parool.nl/kunst-en-media/kaarten-voor-beyonce-in-de-arena-razendsnel-weg~a4245000/|title=Tickets for Beyoncé in the Arena rapidly away|language=Dutch|work=[[Het Parool]]|date=15 February 2016|accessdate=16 February 2016}} [[Armin van Buuren]] played the venue twice in May 2017 as part of his the Best of Armin Only world tour in celebration of 20 years in music. He was the First Solo DJ to do so.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/7573346/armin-van-buuren-20th-anniversary-best-of-armin-only/|title=Armin van Buuren Announces US Tour Dates, 'Best of Armin Only' 20th Anniversary Show| language=English|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=10 November 2016|accessdate=10 November 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Association football|Amsterdam}} {{commons category|Johan Cruijff ArenA|Johan Cruyff Arena}} *{{official website}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080617184749/http://english.ajax.nl/web/show/id%3D49214 Ajax Museum] {{Template group |title = Articles related to the Johan Cruyff Arena |list = {{UEFA Euro 2000 stadiums}} {{UEFA Euro 2020 stadiums}} {{UEFA Champions League Final venues}} {{Football venues in the Netherlands}} {{List of retractable-roof stadiums in Europe}} {{AFC Ajax}} {{Amsterdam Admirals}} }} [[Category:Sports venues in Amsterdam]] [[Category:Football venues in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Retractable-roof stadiums]] [[Category:European retractable-roof stadiums]] [[Category:UEFA Euro 2000 stadiums in the Netherlands]] [[Category:AFC Ajax facilities]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1996]] [[Category:Music venues in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Amsterdam-Zuidoost]] [[Category:UEFA Euro 2020 stadiums]] [[Category:Johan Cruyff]] [[Category:1996 establishments in the Netherlands]]

{{more footnotes|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox football club| clubname = KOZAF| image = | fullname = Kassoum Ouédraogo Zico Académie de Football| nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Stade Municipal (Ouagadougou)|Stade Municipal]]
[[Ouagadougou]], [[Burkina Faso]]| capacity = 15,000| chairman = | manager = | league = [[Burkinabé Premier League]]| season = 2013–14| position = '''12th''' place| | pattern_la2=_barca1314away|pattern_b2=_fcbarcelona1314away|pattern_ra2=_barca1314away|pattern_so2=_long_barca1314a | leftarm2=FF8F00|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FF8F00|shorts2=FF0000|socks2=FF0000 }} '''Kassoum Ouédraogo Zico Académie de Football''' or simply '''KOZAF''' is a [[Burkina Faso|Burkinabé]] [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Ouagadougou]]. The team currently plays in the [[Burkinabé Premier League]] and plays their home games at the [[Stade Municipal (Ouagadougou)|Stade Municipal]]. The club colours are orange and yellow. ==External links== *[http://www.kozaf.com Official website] *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/burkina-faso/kozaf/25949 Team profile] – ''soccerway.com'' [[Category:Football clubs in Burkina Faso]] [[Category:Sport in Ouagadougou]] {{BurkinaFaso-footyclub-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=November 2006}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = KPT FC| image = [[Image:KPTFClogo.png|140px|KPT FC Logo]]| fullname = Karachi Port Trust Football Club | nickname = The Portmen | founded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|1887}} | ground = [[KPT Football Stadium]],
[[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]] | capacity = 15,000 | chairman = Shah Naeem | mgrtitle = Head Coach | manager = Mohammad Asif | league = [[Pakistan Premier League]] | season = [[2014–15 Pakistan Premier League|2014–15]] | position = Pakistan Premier League, 9th |pattern_la1= _river1718h |pattern_b1= _river1718h |pattern_ra1= _river1718h |pattern_sh1= _adidaswhite |pattern_so1= _3_stripes_red | leftarm1= |body1= |rightarm1= |shorts1=2d5f9e |socks1= FFFFFF |pattern_la2= _shoulder_stripes_white_stripes |pattern_b2=_shoulder_stripes_white_stripes |pattern_ra2= _shoulder_stripes_white_stripes |pattern_sh2= _adidaswhite |pattern_so2= _3_stripes_white | leftarm2= 2d5f9e |body2= 2d5f9e |rightarm2= 2d5f9e |shorts2= 1d1e1f |socks2= 2d5f9e | }} '''Karachi Port Trust F.C.''' is a [[Pakistan]]i football club which plays in the [[Pakistan Premier League]], based in [[Karachi]]. Nicknamed the Portmen, they play their games at the KPT Sports Complex. KPT won the Challenge Cup in 1990. KPT FC and [[Karachi United]] became the most popular football clubs from [[Karachi]]. They are founding members of the PPL and have finished fourth three times. ==Achievements== *'''[[Pakistan National Football Challenge Cup]]: 1''' :: Winners: 1990 :: Runner-up (4): 1987, 1991, 1998, 2003 {{Pakistan Premier League}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kpt Fc}} [[Category:Football clubs in Pakistan]] {{Pakistan-footyclub-stub}}

It is owned by Kris Pillay.[http://fijitimes.com.fj/story.aspx?id=375693 Pillay: Apparelis designed to suit Fijian physicality] Its slogan is "Cultured by Choice Branded with Innovation".[http://www.lesportswear.com/?page_id=32 Contact|Limited Edition Sportswear (LE) Australia] The company has a network of suppliers in [[UK]], [[Australia]], Pacific Islands including [[Samoa]], [[Fiji]], [[New Zealand]] and [[Papua New Guinea]].[http://www.lesportswear.com/?post_type=news&p=1021 New Zealand Rugby League The Southern Partnership] ==Sponsorships== ===Rugby Union=== *{{ru|Samoa}} (since 2016)[http://www.lesportswear.com/?post_type=news&p=336 LE Sportswear is pleased to Announce a 4 year Apparel partnership with Samoa Rugby Union] ===Rugby League=== *{{rl|Fiji}} (until 2017)[http://fijitimes.com.fj/story.aspx?id=375693 Pillay: Apparelis designed to suit Fijian physicality] *[[Wellington Rugby League]][http://www.lesportswear.com/?post_type=news&p=972 Wellington Rugby League Partners with LE Sportswear] *[[South Island Scorpions]][http://www.lesportswear.com/?post_type=news&p=1021 New Zealand Rugby League The Southern Partnership] *[[Northern Swords]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.lesportswear.com/}} [[Category:2008 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Companies established in 2008]] [[Category:Clothing brands of Australia]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Sporting goods brands]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of Australia]] [[Category:Companies based in Brisbane]]

This is a list of sports venues in [[Saudi Arabia]]:
== Riyadh == *[[King Fahd International Stadium]], Opened 1987, Capacity 75,000. *[[Prince Faisal bin Fahd Stadium]], Opened 1971, Capacity 30,000.
== Jeddah == *[[Prince Abdullah al-Faisal Stadium]], Opened 1970, Capacity 25,000. *[[Prince Sultan bin Fahd Stadium]], Opened 1987, Capacity 15,000.
== Others == *[[Department of Education Stadium (Unaizah)]] Opened 1 March 1987, Capacity 10,000. *[[King Abdul Aziz Stadium]] in [[Mecca]], Opened 1986, Capacity 17,000. *[[King Fahd Stadium, Taif]] Opened ?, Capacity 20,000. *[[Prince Abdul Aziz bin Musa'ed Stadium]] Opened ?, Capacity 20,000. *[[Prince Mohamed bin Fahd Stadium]] Opened ?, Capacity 35,000. *[[Prince Mohammed bin Abdul Aziz Stadium]] Opened ?, Capacity 20,000. *[[Prince Saud bin Jalawi Stadium]] Opened 1982, Capacity 20,000. *[[Prince Sultan bin Abdul Aziz Stadium]] Opened ?, Capacity 20,000. {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Sports Venues In Saudi Arabia}} [[Category:Football in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Football venues in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Lists of sports venues|Saudi Arabia]]

{{Orphan|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Majors Stadium | nickname = | image = | fullname = Majors Stadium | location = [[Greenville, Texas|Greenville]], [[Texas]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1929 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1964 | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Phillips Field | tenants =
Greenville Majors
(East Texas League) (1946)
(Big State League) (1947-1950, 1953)
(Sooner State League) (1957) | seating_capacity = | dimensions = }} '''Majors Stadium''' was a baseball field in [[Greenville, TX]] but was originally used as a football field. In the beginning, the field was called Phillips Field but was later altered to allow baseball to be played.http://huntcohc.org/marker1.htm ==Phillips Field== Before Majors Stadium became a baseball diamond, it was used in the early years by local high school football teams. On October 4, 1929, [[Oak Cliff High School|Dallas Oak Cliff]] and [[Greenville Independent School District|Greenville High School]] played the first contest at the venue. The field was transformed for the '''Greenville Majors''' after their first year of existence.https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Greenville%2C_TX In 1947, the football stands were removed and the stands were rebuilt to accommodate [[baseball]]. ===Visit by the Yankees=== The [[New York Yankees]] played the Greenville Majors on April 10, 1949, in an exhibition game. The Majors won the game, 4-3.{{cite news |first=Brad |last=Kellar |newspaper=[[Herald-Banner]] |location=[[Greenville, TX]] |title=At the old ball game |url=http://www.heraldbanner.com/local/x2015922716/At-the-old-ball-game |date=April 10, 2013 |accessdate=April 10, 2014}}{{cite news |first=Eric |last=Aasen |publisher=[[KERA-TV]] |title=65 Years Ago Today, The New York Yankees Played In Greenville – And The Home Team Won |location=[[Dallas, TX]] |url=http://keranews.org/post/65-years-ago-today-new-york-yankees-played-greenville-and-home-team-won |date=April 10, 2014 |accessdate=April 10, 2014}} ==Remnants== The only parts left are the arched entryway and a fieldhouse where the field used to exist.http://www.ballparkreviews.com/gvilletx/gvilletx.htmhttp://shroom.aminus3.com/image/2009-03-17.html ==Sources== *{{cite book |title=Texas Almanac 2008-2009 |publisher=[[Texas State Historical Association]] |date=September 14, 2007 |isbn=978-0-914-51141-0}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{coord missing|Texas}} [[Category:High school football venues in Texas]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Texas]] [[Category:Baseball venues in the Prairies and Lakes region (Texas)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1929]] {{Texas-baseball-venue-stub}}

{{Primary sources|date=January 2010}} {{Infobox stadium |stadium_name = McMorran Arena |nickname = McMorran |image = |location = 701 McMorran Boulevard, [[Port Huron, Michigan]] 48060 |broke_ground = August 24, 1958 |built = |opened = January 21, 1960 |closed = |demolished = |owner = City of Port Huron, Michigan |operator = City of Port Huron, Michigan |surface = Multi-surface |construction_cost = 1960: $3,500,000
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|3500000|1960}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) |architect = Alden Dow |former_names = |tenants = [[Port Huron Flags|Port Huron Flags/Wings]] ([[International Hockey League (1945–2001)|IHL]]) (1962–1981)
[[Port Huron Clippers]] ([[All-American Hockey League|AAHL]]) (1987–1988)
[[Port Huron Border Cats]] ([[United Hockey League|UHL]]) (1996–2002)
[[Port Huron Beacons]] (UHL) (2002–2005)
[[Port Huron Flags (UHL)|Port Huron Flags]] (UHL) (2005–2007)
[[Port Huron Pirates]] ([[Continental Indoor Football League|GLIFL/CIFL]]) (2006–2007)
[[Port Huron Icehawks]] ([[International Hockey League (2007–2010)|IHL]]) (2007–2010)
[[Port Huron Fighting Falcons]] ([[North American Hockey League|NAHL]]) (2010–2014)
[[Port Huron Predators]] (CIFL) (2011)
[[Port Huron Patriots]] (CIFL) (2012–2014)
[[Port Huron Prowlers]] ([[Federal Hockey League|FHL]]) (2015–present) |seating_capacity = Hockey or indoor football: 3,400
Concerts: 4,800 |}} '''McMorran Arena''' is an entertainment complex in [[Port Huron, Michigan]] consisting of a 4,800-seat multi-purpose arena and a theater. It was designed by [[Alden B. Dow]] and built in 1960 for $3.5 million (equivalent to ${{Inflation|US|3.5|1960|r=0}} million today).{{cite web |url=http://www.mcmorran.com/arena.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211083244/http://www.mcmorran.com/arena.htm |archivedate=2008-12-11 |df= }} == Sports == As of the 2015-2016 season, McMorran will be the home of the [[Port Huron Prowlers]] of the [[Federal Hockey League]]. Previous hockey tenants include the [[Port Huron Flags]] (various incarnations), [[Port Huron Wings]], [[Port Huron Border Cats]], [[Port Huron Beacons]], [[Port Huron Icehawks]] and [[Port Huron Fighting Falcons]]. In addition, the arena has also been home to three prior indoor football teams; the [[Port Huron Pirates]], [[Port Huron Predators]] and [[Port Huron Patriots]]. == Arena == The arena seats 3,400 for [[ice hockey]] and [[indoor American football|indoor football]], and 4,800 for [[concert]]s. The arena floor measures 85 feet by 185 feet (27 by 62 meters). The dasher boards have 8-foot glass on the ends and 4-foot glass on the sides for ice hockey. The arena is also used for conventions, circuses, ice shows, trade shows, and banquets, among other events.The arena has hosted many major headlining musicians throughout the years such as [[Kiss (band)|KISS]], [[Aerosmith]], [[Ted Nugent]], [[Van Halen]], [[Bon Jovi]], [[Rush (band)|Rush]], [[Ozzy Osbourne]], [[Ratt]], [[Johnny Cash]]. The 1998 opening of [[RBC Centre (Sarnia)|RBC Centre]] in [[Sarnia, Ontario]] sent most of the arena's concert business across the [[St. Clair River]], which separates Port Huron from Sarnia. However, in 2010 McMorran started to rejuvenate their concert lineup with the band [[Third Eye Blind]]. In 2012, McMorran Arena and the adjacent pavilion were used for the Devil's Asylum [[Haunted attraction (simulated)|haunted house]]. As a result, the Fighting Falcons began their season on the road. == Pavilion == The pavilion features {{convert|25000|sqft|m2}} of space for sporting events, trade shows, banquets, meetings, and conventions. In 2016, the city of Port Huron sold the pavilion to St. Clair County Community College for $1. Following the transaction, the Port Huron Minor Hockey Association, which was housed at the Pavilion, merged with the Blue Water Hockey Association, which is run out of Glacier Pointe Ice Complex in Port Huron. SC4 is renovating the building, and will open it in October as the SC4 Fieldhouse. It will serve as the home to SC4's athletic teams. It will also be available for community use, hosting tournaments, showcases and camps in various sports and at various levels.http://www.thetimesherald.com/story/news/local/port-huron/2016/07/01/sc4-fieldhouse-open-oct-3/86545630/ == Theatre == The 1,157-seat theatre is used for Broadway shows, movies, concerts, and other stage events. It features not only excellent acoustics and sight lines, but also a stage curtain, also designed by [[Alden B. Dow]]. It is home to the International Symphony Orchestra and the [[Port Huron Civic Theatre]]. In addition, there is a meeting room and a lounge at the complex. Outside the building is a {{convert|22|ft|m|adj=mid|-diameter}} clock and the Night and Day fountain, both by sculptor [[Marshall Fredericks]]. ==See also== *[[List of concert halls]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.mcmorran.com McMorran Arena website] {{Coord|42|58|44|N|82|25|32|W|region:US-MI_type:landmark|display=title}} {{FHL}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mcmorran Arena}} [[Category:Sports venues in Michigan]] [[Category:Port Huron, Michigan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in St. Clair County, Michigan]] [[Category:Concert halls in Michigan]] [[Category:Convention centers in Michigan]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Michigan]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in St. Clair County, Michigan]] [[Category:Music venues completed in 1960]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1960]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1960]] [[Category:1960 establishments in Michigan]] [[Category:Alden B. revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | name = Mỹ Đình National Stadium | nickname = ({{lang-vi|Sân vận động Quốc gia Mỹ Đình}}) | image = My dinh stadium.jpg | caption = The exterior of Mỹ Đình National Stadium | location = [[Nam Từ Liêm]], [[Hanoi]], [[Vietnam]] | coordinates = {{Coord|21|1|14|N|105|45|49.7|E|}} | broke_ground = 2002 | built = 2002–2003 | opened = 2 September 2003 | renovated = 7 September 2016 | expanded = | owner = [[Politics of Vietnam|Vietnamese Government]] | operator = Vietnam National Sports Complex | surface = Grass | construction_cost = US$ 53 million | architect = [[Hanoi International Group]], [[HISG]] | former_names = | tenants = [[Vietnam national football team]] (2003–present)
[[Vietnam women's national football team]] (2003–present) | capacity = 40,192 | record_attendance = | dimensions = }} The '''Mỹ Đình National Stadium''' ({{lang-vi|Sân vận động Quốc gia Mỹ Đình}}) is a multi-use stadium in [[Nam Từ Liêm]], [[Hanoi]] ([[Vietnam]]). It has a capacity of 40,192 seats and is the centerpiece of Vietnam's National Sports Complex. It was officially opened in September 2003 and was the main venue for the [[2003 Southeast Asian Games|Southeast Asian Games]] later that year, hosting the opening and closing ceremony as well as the men's [[Association football|football]] and athletics events.{{cite web |url=http://thethao.tuoitre.vn/The-thao/159/San-van-dong-quoc-gia-My-Dinh-san-sang-phuc-vu-SEA-Games.html |title=Sân vận động quốc gia Mỹ Đình sẵn sàng phục vụ SEA Games |language=Vietnamese |work=Tuổi Trẻ online |date=2 September 2003 |accessdate=13 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130323025552/http://thethao.tuoitre.vn/The-thao/159/San-van-dong-quoc-gia-My-Dinh-san-sang-phuc-vu-SEA-Games.html |archivedate=23 March 2013 |df= }} The stadium is home to the [[Vietnam national football team]], and hosts its home international friendly matches. It was also home to [[Thể Công]] from 2005 to 2008. It is currently home to [[Viettel F.C.]], with the stadium being its home since 2010. Located 10 kilometres north-west of central Hanoi, the 40,000-seat stadium is the second biggest in the country in terms of capacity and was built at a cost of US$53 million. Arched roofs cover the grandstands on the east and west sides of the arena, providing shelter for half of the seats. The area provides training facilities for the teams with two football training grounds conveniently located next to the stadium. ==History== Ideas for a new national stadium in Vietnam were marked up in 1998 as the government conducted a prefeasibility study for a national sports complex.{{cite web|title=Làm trái phê duyệt vẫn trúng thầu|url=https://nld.com.vn/thoi-su-trong-nuoc/lam-trai-phe-duyet-van-trung-thau-79444.htm|website=Người Lao Động|accessdate=13 April 2018|language=vi}} In July 2000, [[Vietnamese Prime Minister]] [[Phan Văn Khải]] approved a project of a stadium at the heart of Vietnam's National Sports Complex in preparation for hosting the [[2003 Southeast Asian Games]]. Four firms, namely Hanoi International Group (HISG - China), [[Philipp Holzmann]] (Germany), [[Bouygues]] (France) and Lemna-Keystone (United States), participated in the bidding of the stadium's construction. The process was controversial due to violations of technical and financial requirements in HISG and Holzmann's bids, corruption allegations involving a French donation as well as the intransparency in the panel's decision making.{{cite web|title=Chính phủ không chấp nhận nhà thầu Philipp Holzmann|url=https://kinhdoanh.vnexpress.net/tin-tuc/vi-mo/chinh-phu-khong-chap-nhan-nha-thau-philipp-holzmann-2664666.html|website=VNExpress|accessdate=13 April 2018|language=vi}}{{cite web|author1=Ngọc Ẩn|author2=K. Xuân|title=Nếu chọn nhà thầu Âu, Mỹ, chất lượng sân Mỹ Đình đã khác|url=https://tuoitre.vn/neu-chon-nha-thau-au-my-chat-luong-san-my-dinh-da-khac-1076557.htm|website=Tuổi Trẻ Online|accessdate=13 April 2018|language=vi}}{{cite web|title=Phía TQ vẫn trúng thầu xây sân vận động Quốc gia VN|url=https://www.rfa.org/vietnamese/features/63134-20010815.html|website=[[Radio Free Asia]]|accessdate=13 April 2018|language=vi}} In the end, HISG won the bid and signed a commitment contract on August 14, 2001. Construction on the stadium started in 2002. During the developmental phase, the stadium was referred to as ''Sân vận động Trung tâm'' ("central stadium"). The stadium was architecturally complete in June 2003. In August 2003, the stadium was officially named ''Mỹ Đình National Stadium'', taking after the name of the commune area the stadium is located within. It was inaugurated on September 2, 2003 to coincide with [[National Day (Vietnam)|Vietnam's National Day]].{{cite web|title=Sân vận động quốc gia mang tên Mỹ Đình|url=https://thethao.vnexpress.net/tin-tuc/bong-da-quoc-te-giai-ngoai-hang-anh/san-van-dong-quoc-gia-mang-ten-my-dinh-1046952.html|website=VNExpress|accessdate=13 April 2018}} ==Interior== [[File:Khán đài B - Sân vận động Quốc gia Mỹ Đình.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Mỹ Đình National Stadium]] ===Stands=== Mỹ Đình has 4 stands. The A & B stands (or east and west stands, respectively) are covered each by an arched roof weighing 2,300 tonnes. These two stands have two tiers and are {{cvt|25.8|m|ft}} tall while the C & D stands (or south and north stands) are single-tiered and {{cvt|8.4|m|ft}} tall. In total, the stadium has a capacity of 40,192 seats, including 450 VIP seats and 160 seats for journalists. ===Field=== The playing grass field has a size of 105m x 67m, surrounded by an 8-lane [[athletics (sport)|athletics]] track and other athletics facilities. ==Events== ===Sporting events=== The stadium officially opened on September 2, 2003 with the opening [[exhibition game|friendly match]] between the [[Vietnam national under-23 football team|Vietnam U23]] and [[Shanghai Shenhua F.C.|Shanghai Shenhua]] from [[Chinese Super League]]. It hosted the [[2003 Southeast Asian Games]] ([[2003 Southeast Asian Games#Opening ceremony|opening ceremony]], [[Football at the 2003 Southeast Asian Games|football]] and [[Athletics at the 2003 Southeast Asian Games|athletics]], [[2003 Southeast Asian Games#Closing ceremony|closing ceremony]]) and [[2003 ASEAN Para Games]]. In July 2007, Mỹ Đình Stadium hosted the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup Group B|Group B of 2007 AFC Asian Cup]] along with [[Quân khu 7 Stadium]] ([[Ho Chi Minh City]]), [[2007 AFC Asian Cup#quarter-finals|quarter-final match]] (Japan vs Australia) and [[2007 AFC Asian Cup#Semi-finals|semi-final match]] (Japan vs Saudi Arabia). Mỹ Đình Stadium held the opening ceremony of the [[2009 Asian Indoor Games]] from October 30, 2009 to November 8. In December 2010, it held [[2010 AFF Suzuki Cup Group B|Group B of 2010 AFF Suzuki Cup]] from December 2 to December 8. In addition, this stadium held many domestic and international football competitions: * [[2008 AFC Champions League]] ([[Nam Định F.C.|Nam Định]] selected this stadium as their own [[Thiên Trường Stadium]] did not meet AFC criteria{{cite web |url=http://ngoisao.net/tin-tuc/ben-le/2008/02/nam-dinh-di-cu-len-my-dinh-da-cup-c1-chau-a-93636/ |title=Nam Định 'di cư' lên Mỹ Đình đá Cup C1 châu Á |author=Thế Ngọc |date=February 22, 2008 |work=Ngoisao.net |publisher=Ngoisao.net |accessdate=December 5, 2011|language=Vietnamese}}). * 2008 The stadium held an [[exhibition game|international friendly match]] between [[Vietnam national football team|Vietnam]] and [[Brazil national under-23 football team|Olympic Brazil]]. * [[2010 VFF Cup]]. * [[2011 V-League]] (25th round match between [[Hà Nội ACB]] and [[Sông Lam Nghệ An F.C.|Sông Lam Nghệ An]]{{cite web |url=http://www.vff.org.vn/default.aspx?mod=DetailNews&fNewsID=16453&fCatID=272&fSncID=&fMscID=|title=Thông báo số 29 Giải VĐQG Eximbank 2011|author=Dương Nghiệp Khôi|date=July 29, 2011|work=VFF.org.vn|publisher=[[Vietnam Football Federation]]|accessdate=July 30, 2011|language=Vietnamese}}). * [[2011 VFF Cup]]. * [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's Asian Qualifiers Playoff Round|2012 Football at the Summer Olympics – Men's Asian Qualifiers Playoff Round]] The three runners-up from the third round groups played each other at a neutral venue on 25, 27 and 29 March 2012. Vietnam was later chosen by the AFC Competitions Committee as the neutral venue, with games played at Hanoi's Mỹ Đình Stadium. * On 17 July 2013, the stadium held an [[exhibition game|international friendly match]] between [[Vietnam national football team|Vietnam]] and [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. * On 27 July 2015, the stadium held an international friendly match between [[Vietnam national football team|Vietnam]] and [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]. ===Major sports matches=== ====2003 Southeast Asian Games==== {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="100%" |- !Date !Time (UTC+7) !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- | 30 November 2003||15:00||{{fbu|23|IDN}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–0||{{fbu|23|LAO}}||Group A (opening match)||{{n/a}} |- | 30 November 2003||17:30||{{fbu|23|THA}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–1||{{fbu|23|VIE}}||Group A||{{n/a}} |- | 9 December 2003||16:00||{{fbu|23|THA}}||style="text-align:center;"|2–0||{{fbu|23|MYA|1974}}||Semi-final||{{n/a}} |- | 9 December 2003||19:00||{{fbu|23|VIE}}||style="text-align:center;"|4–3||{{fbu|23|MAS}}||Semi-final||{{n/a}} |- | 12 December 2003||16:30||{{fbu|23|MAS}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–1 (4–2 [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|pen.]])||{{fbu|23|MYA|1974}}||Bronze medal match||{{n/a}} |-bgcolor=gold | 12 December 2003||19:00||{{fbu|23|THA}}||style="text-align:center;"|2–1||{{fbu|23|VIE}}||Final||{{n/a}} |} ====2007 AFC Asian Cup==== {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="100%" |- !Date !Time (UTC+7) !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- | 8 July 2007||19:30||{{fb|VIE}}||style="text-align:center;"|2–0||{{fb|UAE}}||Group B||39,450 |- | 9 July 2007||20:30||{{fb|UAE}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–3||{{fb|JPN}}||Group B||5,000 |- | 16 July 2007||17:15||{{fb|VIE}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–4||{{fb|JPN}}||Group B||40,000 |- | 21 July 2007||17:15||{{fb|JPN}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–1 (4–3 [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|pen.]])||{{fb|AUS}}||Quarter-final||25,000 |- | 25 July 2007||20:15||{{fb|JPN}}||style="text-align:center;"|2–3||{{fb|SAU}}||Semi-final||10,000 |} ===Entertainment events=== [[File:Huge crowd turns out for MTV EXIT concert against human trafficking and exploitation.jpg|200px|thumb|left|MTV EXIT concert at Mỹ Đình National Stadium]] Mỹ Đình National Stadium has hosted many entertainment events. On January 10, 2010, [[Vietnam Television|VTV]] held a concert featuring local famous singers. On March 27, 2010, a MTV Exit concert was held here with the appearance of [[Super Junior]], a Korean boyband, [[Kate Miller]], an Australian singer along with many Vietnamese singers. Recently, on October 1, 2011, the Irish boyband [[Westlife]] put a stop here as a part of their [[Gravity Tour]]; about 11,000 people attended the concert. The stadium was also the starting line of [[The Amazing Race Vietnam]] 2012. On May 26, 2013, MTV Exit held a concert featuring the Canadian pop punk band [[Simple Plan]] to raise awareness about human trafficking and modern slavery. The stadium has also been the venue for various [[K-Pop]] concerts. It was the venue for a special concert of [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation|MBC]]'s [[Music Core]] on December 8, 2012 and [[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]]'s [[Music Bank World Tour]] on March 28, 2015. ==References== ==External links== *http://uk.soccerway.com/teams/vietnam/vietnam/7626/venue/ ==See also== *[[List of stadiums by capacity]] {{Hanoi Tourism}} {{2007 AFC Asian Cup stadiums}} {{Coord|21|1|14|N|105|45|49.7|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:My Dinh National Stadium}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2003]] [[Category:Football venues in Vietnam]] [[Category:AFC Asian Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Vietnam]] [[Category:Stadiums in Hanoi]] [[Category:National stadiums|Vietnam]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Vietnam]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Vietnam]]

The '''Peshawar cricket team''' is a Pakistani [[first-class cricket]] team from [[Peshawar]]. The team's home ground is [[Arbab Niaz Stadium]] in Peshawar. The [[List A cricket|List A]] and [[Twenty 20]] side is known as the [[Peshawar Panthers]].
Peshawar first played in first-class competitions in 1956-57, and they have competed in most seasons since then, except for a hiatus between 1977-78 and 1983-84. Apart from a few matches played by [[North-West Frontier Province cricket team|North-West Frontier Province]] in the 1970s, Peshawar were usually the only first-class team from [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] province (formerly known as North-West Frontier Province) until the debut of [[Abbottabad cricket team|Abbottabad]] in 2005-06.
Peshawar won the [[Quaid-i-Azam Trophy]] in 1998-99 and 2004-05 and the [[ABN-AMRO Cup National One-day Championship]] in 2006-07. They also won the [[Faysal_Bank_Quaid-e-Azam_Trophy_2011–12#Division_II_Final|2011-12 Quaid-e-Azam Trophy Division Two]].
In first-class cricket to the end of 2013 they had played 262 matches, with 82 wins, 99 losses, 80 draws and one tie.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Records/Pakistan/Firstclass/Peshawar/Team_Records/Playing_Record.html Peshawar first-class playing record]</ref> Their highest individual score is 300 not out, by [[Shoaib Khan (cricketer, born 1978)|Shoaib Khan]] against [[Quetta cricket team|Quetta]] in 2003-04.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Records/Pakistan/Firstclass/Peshawar/Batting_Records/Highest_Innings_For.html Highest scores for Peshawar]</ref> Their best bowling figures are 9 for 62 by [[Safiullah Khan (cricketer, born 1940)|Safiullah Khan]] against [[Pakistan Railways cricket team|Railways B]] in 1971-72.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Records/Pakistan/Firstclass/Peshawar/Bowling_Records/Best_Innings_Bowling_For.html Most wickets in an innings for Peshawar]</ref>
In [[List A cricket]] they have played 73 times, with 22 wins, 49 losses, one tie and one no-result.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Records/Pakistan/ListA/Peshawar/Team_Records/Playing_Record.html Peshawar List A playing record]</ref>
Peshawar's notable players have included [[Haseeb Ahsan]] (their first Test player), [[Younis Khan]], [[Yasir Hameed]], [[Fazl-e-Akbar]], [[Wajahatullah Wasti]], [[Umar Gul]] and [[Arshad Khan (cricketer)|Arshad Khan]].
In January 2017, they won the [[2016–17 Regional One Day Cup]], beating [[Karachi Whites]] by 124 runs in the final.<ref name="201617Reg">{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/pakistan/content/story/1079784.html |title=Gauhar, Iftikhar tons lead Peshawar to title |accessdate=27 January 2017 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}}</ref>
==Current Squad== Players with international caps are listed in bold. <ref name="Squads">{{Cite web|url=http://nation.com.pk/sports/10-Aug-2017/national-t20-cup-to-commence-from-aug-25-in-multan |title=Drafting done as Multan, Faisalabad to host National T20 Cup |accessdate=12 August 2017 |work=The Nation}}</ref>
* '''[[Mohammad Rizwan (cricketer, born 1992)|Mohammad Rizwan]]''' ([[captain (cricket)|c]]) * [[Zohaib Khan]] * [[Israrullah]] * '''[[Imran Khan (cricketer, born 1988)|Imran Khan Jnr]]''' * [[Akbar Badshah]] * [[Musadiq Ahmed]] * [[Naved Yasin]] * [[Waqas Maqsood]] * '''[[Imran Khan (cricketer, born 1987)|Imran Khan]]''' * '''[[Fakhar Zaman (cricketer)|Fakhar Zaman]]''' * '''[[Sohail Khan (cricketer, born 1984)|Sohail Khan]]''' * [[Kashif Bhatti]] * [[Usman Qadir]] * [[Saif Badar]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2016}}
'''Respiratory adaptation''' is the specific changes that the [[respiratory system]] undergoes in response to the demands of [[Physical exercise|physical exertion]]. Intense physical exertion, such as that involved in [[fitness training]], places elevated demands on the respiratory system. Over time, this results in respiratory changes as the system adapts to these requirements.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ptdirect.com/training-design/anatomy-and-physiology/chronic-respiratory-adaptations-to-exercise|title=Respiratory System Adaptations to Exercise|website=www.ptdirect.com|publisher=PT Direct|language=en|access-date=2016-04-05}}</ref> These changes ultimately result in an increased exchange of [[oxygen]] and [[carbon dioxide]], which is accompanied by an increase in [[metabolism]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alley|first=Thomas R.|date=2014-02-25|title=Food sharing and empathic emotion regulation: an evolutionary perspective|journal=Frontiers in Psychology|volume=5|doi=10.3389/fpsyg.2014.00121|issn=1664-1078|pmc=3933786|pmid=24611057}}</ref> Respiratory adaptation is a physiological determinant of peak endurance performance, and in elite athletes, the pulmonary system is often a limiting factor to exercise under certain conditions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McKenzie|first=Donald C.|date=2012-05-01|title=Respiratory physiology: adaptations to high-level exercise|journal=British Journal of Sports Medicine|volume=46|issue=6|pages=381–384|doi=10.1136/bjsports-2011-090824|issn=1473-0480|pmid=22267571}}</ref>
== Neural control == Respiratory adaptation begins almost immediately after the initiation of the physical [[Stress (biology)|stress]] associated with exercise. This triggers signals from the [[motor cortex]] that stimulate the respiratory center of the [[Brainstem|brain stem]], in conjunction with feedback from the [[Proprioception|proprioreceptors]] in the muscles and joints of the active limbs.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.cdc.gov/nccdphp/sgr/pdf/chap3.pdf|title=Physical Activity and Health: A Report of the Surgeon General|last=|first=|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=|chapter=Physiologic Responses and Long-Term Adaptations to Exercise}}</ref>
==Breathing rate== With higher intensity training, [[breathing rate]] is increased in order to allow more air to move in and out of the lungs, which enhances gas exchange. [[Endurance training]] typically results in an increase in the respiration rate.<ref name=":0" />
==Lung capacity== With adaptation, [[Tidal volume|lung capacity]] is increased over time, allowing a greater quantity of air to move in and out. Endurance training typically results in an increase in [[tidal volume]].<ref name=":0" />
==Respiratory muscles== Muscles involved in respiration, including the [[Thoracic diaphragm|diaphragm]] and [[intercostal muscles]], increase in strength and endurance. This results in an improved ability to breathe in more air, for longer amounts of time with less fatigue. [[Aerobic exercise|Aerobic training]] typically improves the endurance of respiratory muscles, whereas [[Anaerobic exercise|anaerobic training]] tends to increase the size and strength of respiratory muscles. <ref name=":1" />
==Lung capillaries== Exercise increases the [[vascularization]] of the lungs. This allows the more blood flow in and out of the lungs. This enhances the uptake of oxygen, since there is greater surface area for blood to bind with [[haemoglobin]].<ref name=":1" />
==Alveoli== Respiratory adaptation results an increase in the number of [[Pulmonary alveolus|alveoli]], which enables more gas exchange to occur. This is coupled with an increase in alveolar oxygen tension.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hurtado|first=Alberto|date=30 September 1934|title=Respiratory adaptation to anoxemia|url=http://ajplegacy.physiology.org/content/109/4/626.article-info|journal=American Journal of Physiology|volume=109|doi=|pmid=|access-date=4 April 2016}}</ref>

[[File:George Sherrill 2008.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[George Sherrill]] has been a setup man for the [[Seattle Mariners]], [[Baltimore Orioles]], and [[Los Angeles Dodgers]]]] In [[baseball]], a '''setup man''' (or '''set-up man''', also sometimes referred to as a '''setup pitcher''' or '''setup reliever''') is a [[relief pitcher]] who regularly pitches before the [[closer (baseball)|closer]]. They commonly pitch the eighth [[inning]], with the closer pitching the ninth.<ref>{{cite book|title=Fireman: The Evolution of the Closer in Baseball|first=Fran|last=Zimniuch|pages=154, 168|publisher=[[Triumph Books]]|location=Chicago|year=2010|isbn=978-1-60078-312-8 |ref=zimniuch}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Felber |first=Bill |title=The Book on the Book: An Inquiry Into Which Strategies in the Modern Game Actually Work |page=102|year=2006 |publisher=[[St. Martin's Griffin]] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-HZ3xF7DT7IC&lpg=PA117&dq=setup%20man&pg=PA102#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-0-312-33265-5 |accessdate=January 5, 2011}}</ref>
As closers were reduced to one-inning specialists, setup men became more prominent.<ref>[[#zimniuch|Zimniuch 2010]], pp.168–9</ref> Setup pitchers often come into the game with the team losing or the game tied.<ref>[[#zimniuch|Zimniuch 2010]], pp.169</ref> They are usually the second best relief pitcher on a team, behind the closer. After closers became one-inning pitchers, primarily in the ninth inning, setup pitchers became more highly valued.<ref>[[#zimniuch|Zimniuch 2010]], p.163</ref> A pitcher who succeeds in this role is often promoted to a closer.<ref>[[#zimniuch|Zimniuch 2010]], pp.165,168,171–3</ref> Setup men are paid less than closers and mostly make less than the average Major League salary.<ref>[[#zimniuch|Zimniuch 2010]], p.169</ref>
The most common statistic used to evaluate relievers is the [[save (baseball)|save]]. Due to the definition of the statistic, setup men are rarely in position to record a save even if they pitch well, but they can be charged with a [[blown save]] if they pitch poorly. The [[hold (baseball)|hold]] statistic was developed to help acknowledge a setup man's effectiveness,<ref>[[#zimniuch|Zimniuch 2010]], pp.169–70</ref> but it is not an official [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) statistic.
Historically, setup men were rarely selected to [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|MLB All-Star Game]]s, with the nod usually going to closers with large save totals.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rancel|first=Tommy|title=Set-up guys who would be worthy All-Stars|date=June 24, 2013|work=ESPN.com|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/sweetspot/post/_/id/37360/set-up-guys-who-would-be-worthy-all-stars|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6TG0Sbru7?url=http://espn.go.com/blog/sweetspot/post/_/id/37360/set-up-guys-who-would-be-worthy-all-stars|archivedate=October 12, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> From 1971 through 2000, only six relievers with fewer than five saves at midseason were selected as All-Stars. There were 10 such players from 2001 through 2009.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kay|first=Joe|title=All Star Game could be decided by setup men|date=July 13, 2015|newspaper=The Star|agency=Associated Press|url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/baseball/2015/07/13/all-star-game-could-be-decided-by-setup-men.html|accessdate=October 12, 2018}}</ref> In [[2015 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|2015]], the majority of the [[American League]]'s All-Star relievers were not closers, outnumbered 4–3.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jennings|first=Chad|title=Yankees’ Betances leading wave of standout setup men|date=July 13, 2015|newspaper=The Journal News|url=https://www.lohud.com/story/sports/mlb/yankees/chad-jennings/2015/07/13/betances-standout-setup-relievers/30111923/|accessdate=October 12, 2018}}</ref> Setup men who have been named All-Stars multiple times include [[Justin Duchscherer]], [[Tyler Clippard]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Kilgore|first=Adam|title=2014 MLB All-Star Game: For Nationals reliever Tyler Clippard, a perfect setup|date=July 14, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/nationals/2014-mlb-all-star-game-for-nationals-reliever-tyler-clippard-a-perfect-set-up/2014/07/14/93f47676-0b5d-11e4-b8e5-d0de80767fc2_story.html|accessdate=October 13, 2018}}</ref> [[Dellin Betances]], and [[Andrew Miller (baseball)|Andrew Miller]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Crasnick|first=Jerry|title=Eight under-the-radar relievers who deserve All-Star consideration|date=June 23, 2018|website=ESPN.com|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/23871684/eight-radar-relievers-deserves-all-star-consideration|accessdate=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
[[Francisco Rodríguez (baseball, born 1982)|Francisco Rodriguez]], who was a setup pitcher for the [[Anaheim Angels]] in 2002,<ref>{{cite news|last=Curry|first=Jack|title=Rodriguez Is a Fantasy Player Like No Other|date=October 11, 2002|newspaper=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/11/sports/baseball-rodriguez-is-a-fantasy-player-like-no-other.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6TFpID1FO?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/11/sports/baseball-rodriguez-is-a-fantasy-player-like-no-other.html|archivedate=October 11, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> tied starting pitcher [[Randy Johnson]]'s Major League Baseball record for [[win (baseball)|wins]] in a single postseason after recording his fifth victory in the [[2002 World Series]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Chuck|title=Rodriguez set to close for Angels|date=February 20, 2005|newspaper=USA Today|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/al/angels/2005-02-20-angels-spring_x.htm|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6TFpSTxW0?url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/al/angels/2005-02-20-angels-spring_x.htm|archivedate=October 11, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
[[Tim McCarver]] wrote that the [[New York Yankees]] in 1996 "revolutionized baseball" with [[Mariano Rivera]], "a middle reliever who should have been on the All-Star team and who was a legitimate MVP candidate."<ref name=zimniuch_p221>[[#zimniuch|Zimniuch 2010]], p.221</ref> He finished third in the voting for the [[American League]] (AL) [[Cy Young Award]],<ref name=96cy>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1996.shtml#ALcya|title=1996 Awards Voting|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|publisher=Sports Reference LLC|accessdate=January 9, 2012}}</ref> the highest a setup man has finished. That season, Rivera primarily served as a setup pitcher for closer [[John Wetteland]], typically pitching in the seventh and eighth inning of games before Wetteland pitched in the ninth. Their effectiveness gave the Yankees a 70–3 [[win–loss record (pitching)|win–loss record]] that season when leading after six innings.<ref>[[#zimniuch|Zimniuch 2010]], pp.219–221</ref> McCarver said the Yankees played "six-inning games" that year, with Rivera dominating for two innings and Wetteland closing out the victory.<ref name=zimniuch_p221/>
Illustrating the general trend, both Rivera and Rodriguez were moved to closer soon after excelling as setup men.

[[Montpellier Hérault Rugby|Montpellier RC]] (until 2007) | embedded = | website = }} '''Stade Sabathé''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Montpellier]], [[France]]. It is currently used mostly for [[rugby union]] and [[rugby league]] matches and is the home stadium of [[Montpellier Red Devils]]. Until 2007 it was the home stadium of [[Montpellier Hérault Rugby|Montpellier RC]]. The stadium is able to hold 6,500 people.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/europe/countries/france/languedoc_roussillion.shtml |title=Stadiums in France Languedoc-Roussillon|publisher=Worldstadiums.com|accessdate=14 October 2011}} ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Stade Sabathe}} [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in France|Sabathe]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in France|Sabathe]] [[Category:Sport in Montpellier]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Montpellier]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hérault]] [[Category:Montpellier Hérault Rugby]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1930]] {{France-sports-venue-stub}}

The '''University Golf Match''' (commonly known as the Varsity Match) is the annual [[golf]] match contested between the [[Blue (university sport)|Full Blue]] golf teams from [[Oxford University|Oxford]] and [[Cambridge University Golf Club|Cambridge]] universities. Dating back to 1878, it is the oldest amateur event in golf, as the first [[Amateur Championship]] was played in 1885. It is also the oldest team event in English golf. Scottish team matches were common after 1849, and included St Andrews University matches against Fife artisan clubs.<ref>"The Early Years of University Golf", John Gillum, 1997</ref> The Varsity Match was most recently contested in March 2018, at Royal Porthcawl Golf Club, and was won by Cambridge.
==History== The first University Golf Match was played on 6 March 1878 at [[Wimbledon Common]], courtesy of [[London Scottish Golf Club]], which hosted the fixture for 19 years until it moved to [[Royal St George's Golf Club]] in 1897.<ref name="Gillum">John Gillum, ''The Oxford and Cambridge Golfing Society: 100 Years of Serious Fun'', [[Grant Books]], 1997.</ref> The match was contested by four singles matches, and used the [[holes up]] method of scoring. Oxford, led by [[Horace Hutchinson]], won by a margin of 24 holes.<ref name="Gillum" /> Up to and including 2013, 124 University Golf Matches have been played.
In 1898 the Oxford and Cambridge Golfing Society (OCGS) was founded; members qualify by virtue of their participation in the University Golf Match. Since 1920, the OCGS has hosted the [[President's Putter]], an annual match-play competition for its members held at Rye Golf Club, in [[Rye]], [[East Sussex]].<ref>John Barton, [http://www.golfdigest.com/magazine/2009/12/presidents_putter_john_barton The Presidents Putter], ''[[Golf Digest]]'' (December, 2009).</ref>
==Venues== Until the 1890s there were very few golf courses in England, and none of appropriate quality in the Oxford and Cambridge areas. The University Match was initially played on Wimbledon Common, which, along with [[Royal Blackheath]], was one of just a handful of courses in the London area at the time.
Since then, the University Golf Match has been played at courses all over the United Kingdom, including [[Royal St George's Golf Club|Royal St George's]], [[Royal Cinque Ports Golf Club|Royal Cinque Ports]], [[Royal Liverpool Golf Club|Royal Liverpool]], [[Muirfield]], [[Ganton, North Yorkshire|Ganton]], [[Walton Heath Golf Club|Walton Heath]], [[Hunstanton]], [[Aldeburgh]], [[Royal Porthcawl Golf Club|Royal Porthcawl]], and [[Sunningdale Golf Club|Sunningdale]].
The choice of venue alternates between the teams, and the match is traditionally played every five years at Rye (last played at Rye in 2014).
The 2019 Match will be played at [[Rye Golf Club]].
==Present-day competition== Men - Each team comprises ten players plus two reserves. The reserves traditionally play the "Dinner Match" on the Thursday of the Varsity Match week: an 18-hole alternate shot [[foursomes]] match, followed by an 18-hole singles match. The losing team is responsible for paying the bill for the Varsity Match dinner on the Saturday evening.
The University Match itself is contested over the course of two days. Five 36-hole foursomes matches are played on the Friday, and ten 36-hole singles matches are played on the Saturday.
Ladies – 18-hole foursomes followed by 18 singles contested between 6 ladies from each team, with one reserve. Although the reserved play a match the score does not count towards the final score. The Ladies' match is held on the Tuesday of Varsity week as the beginning of the matches.
